thread.title_full: Draw announced for women’s Olympic boxing trials

author: Pete Wickham
title: Draw announced for women’s Olympic boxing trials
text:
They mixed up the 24 competitors for the 2016 USA Olympic Women's Boxing Team Trials during Sunday night's draw at the Crowne Plaza East, and will turn them loose Monday evening and all week at Cook Convention Center.
And the three top seeds believe the second go-round for women's boxing at next summer's Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro could produce an American sweep of all three women's boxing gold medals.
"I think we have a killer opportunity to get all three (golds)," said top-seeded lightweight Mikaela Mayer of Los Angeles, the reigning USA Boxing national champion in her class. "There's so much talent here, and if it's not the same girls it will be new girls with the chance ... but I also know that possibility will get tougher because now that we have the opportunity, girls are coming out of nowhere and filling gyms in all corners of the world.
"I've put 10 years of my life into this," Mayer added. "I reached the finals as an unseeded fighter in 2012, and am back as a No. 1 seed, so it shows how far I've come."
Marlen Esparza of Houston took bronze in the featherweight class as women's boxing debuted in the 2012 London Games, and followed up with a world championship last fall in South Korea.
"Claressa (Shields, who won the middleweight gold in London) and I medaled at the Olympics, and there are girls throughout the field who have won on the world stage," Esparza said. "We have a huge chance of sweeping, and it would be the sweetest thing on Earth."
Shields and Esparza were the only American fighters to medal in London as the men (not counting the '80 Moscow Games boycott) were shut out for the first time in a century. And Shields added, "Every time we fight overseas, the women always do better than the men."
There's a reason, she said. "Guys don't know how to let the ego go," she said. "They sometimes think, 'I'm a man. I know how to fight. All I need is to have the judges on my side.' That keeps them from listening to coaches, or concentrating on conditioning."
Shields, 20, added that she and her fellow competitors will have to win three fights when they step into the ring this week in Memphis. "We're fighting just to be on Team USA. We're fighting against people who say women can't fight, that they aren't skilled. And we have to prove ourselves to the judges."
"I like to be positive, while thinking realistic," said Mike Martino, executive director of USA Boxing. "Women's boxing is much more competitive now than in 2012. But Claressa is a special athlete in that boxing seems to come so naturally for (her). Marlen has skills and loads of experience, and coming off wins in the World Championships you'd have to see them as favorites. And I'm excited about how competitive we'll be in all three weight divisions in Rio."
Action starts at noon Monday with more than 400 men seeking one of the final 20 spots in the U.S. Olympic Men's Team Trials in Reno, Nevada, Dec. 7-12. A pair of Memphis amateurs, Macro Hall and Adam Young, are among the hopefuls. Reaching the finals will punch a fighter's ticket for Reno.
The trials, promoted by USA Boxing and Prize Fight Boxing, will have noon and 6 p.m. sessions at Cook Convention Center through Friday, with the finals set for 7 p.m. Saturday at the Cannon Center.
Olympic Boxing Trials
What: U.S. Olympic women's boxing trials and men's trials qualifier
When, where: Monday-Friday at Cook Convention Center, Saturday at the Cannon Center
Who: Twenty-four women will compete for three spots on the U.S. Olympic team headed to Rio de Janeiro for the 2016 Summer Games. Meanwhile, 414 men will compete for the final 20 spots at the U.S. Olympic men's boxing trials Dec. 7-12 at Reno, Nevada.
Daily sessions: Noon (men) and 6 p.m. (women, men) Monday-Friday; 7 p.m. (finals). Saturday
Tickets: $15 (general admission), $25 (VIP Circle), available at the box office or through Ticketmaster. Portion of the proceeds will go to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital. Promoted by: USA Boxing, Prize Fight Boxing
Principal sponsors: City Gear, Homer Skelton Hyundai
For more info: teamusa.org/USA-Boxing
FIRST-ROUND PAIRINGS
Flyweight (107-112 pounds): Marlen Esparza, Houston, vs. Melanie Costa, Norton, Massachusetts; Giovanna Camacho, Toa Alta, Puerto Rico, vs. Christina Cruz, New York; Jamie Mitchell, Las Vegas, vs. Amanda Pavone, Burlington, Massachusetts; Virginia Fuchs, Kemah, Texas, vs. Alex Love, Monroe, Washington.
Lightweight (126-132 pounds): Mikaela Mayer, Los Angeles, vs. Stalacia Leggett, Lancaster, California; Samantha Kinchen, Lexington, Kentucky, vs. Jajaira Gonzalez, Glendora, California; Lisa Porter, San Diego, vs. Rianna Rios, Alice, Texas; Tiara Brown, Fort Myers, Florida, vs. Amelia Moore, Norway, Maine.
Middleweight (153-165 pounds): Claressa Shields, Flint, Michigan, vs. Naomi Graham, Fayetteville, North Carolina; Danyelle Wolf, York, Pennsylvania, vs. Tika Hemingway, Pittsburgh; Francon Crews, Baltimore, vs. Iesha Kenney, Alexandria, Virginia; Raquel Miller, San Francisco, vs. Cierra Taylor, Rochester, New York.
